docs.lead_paragraph: There are many legitimate reasons for eating vegetarian. But according to a recent article published in the journal The Physician and Sports Medicine, the practice of vegetarianism may be a red flag for eating disorders in young athletic women. The article cited numerous studies that found an association between meatless diets and eating disorders, including a 1997 Michigan survey of 107 female adolescents who did not eat meat and 214 who did. Those who did not eat meat were found to diet twice as often, vomit four times as often and use laxatives eight times as often as those in the meat-eating group. All of these practices are commonly linked with eating disorders like anorexia nervosa and bulimia.

headline.main: When Vegetarianism Raises a Red Flag

docs.abstract: Study finds that practice of vegetarianism may be a red flag for eating disorders in young athletic women (S)
docs.snippet: There are many legitimate reasons for eating vegetarian. But according to a recent article published in the journal The Physician and Sports Medicine, the practice of vegetarianism may be a red flag for eating disorders in young athletic women.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: You can't see it, hear it, smell it, taste it or feel it. But it can poison or even kill you without you ever realizing it's around. It is the deadly gas, carbon monoxide, and winter is the season it does most of its damage. Despite annual warnings about the many sources of carbon monoxide and how problems can be prevented and detected before it's too late, this product of combustion kills an estimated 2,100 people who did not intend to die and sickens 10,000 others in the United States each year. All too often, the flu-like symptoms that are early warning signs of carbon monoxide poisoning are mistakenly attributed to a viral infection, and victims are sent home or back to work to breathe yet more of the deadly gas. Babies and small children (including unborn children), those with chronic heart or lung diseases and the elderly are especially sensitive to the harmful effects of carbon monoxide and are among those who are least likely to respond appropriately to the first signs of trouble.

headline.main: Watching for the Warning Signs of an Invisible Killer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dangers posed by carbon monoxide poisoning, and steps to guard against it; table shows effects on body of varying percentages of carbon monoxide (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Just show up with a T-shirt, workout-type clothing,'' said Lee Roy Longenbach, a manager at Metropolis Fencing, when I called to sign up for a few classes. They were not the words I wanted to hear.

headline.main: How Errol Flynn Made It Look So Easy

docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser, in The Novice column, describes her experience taking beginning classes in fencing; notes fencing combines speed, stamina, agility and healthy dose of strategy in a blur of metal and cloth; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I recently spent a week as a ''night float'' at a major New York City teaching hospital, staying up all night while other residents slept. My shift began at 5 P.M., when residents departed for the day, and ended at 7 the next morning, when they returned. Meanwhile, I was responsible for up to 80 very sick patients. One night, shortly after sign-out, a patient with colon cancer began thrashing about wildly and hallucinating. What might be wrong with him? I had no clue. What were the results of his blood tests? I did not know. Could I reassure his family about the results of his brain scan? I would have to get back to them.

headline.main: When Rules for Better Care Exact Their Own Cost

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar reports on controversy over long working hours expected of young medical residents; describes his own experience spending a week as a 'night float' at major New York City teaching hospital, staying up all night while other residents slept; describes pressures of being responsible for up to 80 very sick patients, trying to grapple with potentially serious problems with not enough information; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever become livid at the sight of a parking ticket anchored under his windshield wiper will not be surprised by what scientists have recently quantified: an average of three times a day, a traffic-enforcement agent has a hostile confrontation with a member of the public. Taking advantage of this real-life laboratory, researchers at two New York universities used parking-ticket writers to understand how heart rate and blood pressure may change during verbal conflicts. After equipping 115 New York traffic agents with blood pressure cuffs that took readings every 15 minutes during the work day, scientists discovered that any communication the agents engaged in -- conversations with supervisors, the public, or co-workers -- led to increases in blood pressure and heart rate when compared with baseline readings taken at the start of the work day. Blood pressure readings were highest during interactions with members of the public, and the effects remained after contact ended, according to the study, which appears this month in the journal Psychophysiology.
docs.abstract: Researchers at two New York universities use parking-ticket writers to understand how heart rate and blood pressure may change during verbal conflicts (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like that favorite nursery rhyme egg, children commonly suffer great falls not only off walls, but they also tumble from changing tables, jungle gyms and down stairs. Older children bump heads on playing fields or fall off bicycles. Most end up with only a bad headache, but sometimes complications require emergency treatment and hospitalization. That leaves parents with this often perplexing question: When is a head injury minor and when should it involve a trip to the emergency room?

headline.main: Taking Care of Those Bumps on the Head

docs.abstract: Advice to parents whose child may have suffered bump to head, and how to determine when is a head injury minor, and when should it involve trip to emergency room (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A team led by a St. Louis neurosurgeon has performed the first surgery on a human using superconducting magnets to direct a surgical instrument into the brain, around corners or on a curved path, to reach and perform a biopsy on a tumor. The technique enabled the surgeons to eliminate the requirement -- and the danger -- of pushing a needle through important areas of the brain. Dr. Ralph Dacey, head of neurosurgery at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, said the new magnetic-surgery system is less invasive and should prove safer than traditional methods. It combines computers, magnetic resonance imaging (M.R.I.), X-rays and small superconducting magnets to place surgical instruments or medication in precisely the right spot without disturbing sensitive areas nearby.

headline.main: Using Magnets on Corners of the Mind
